headline: Bean Soup
description: This hearty bean soup is made with a ham bone, cubed ham, navy beans, carrots, and celery. It's so flavorful and tastes even better on the second day!
name: Bean Soup

recipeInstructions.text: Rinse beans; transfer to a large stockpot and add water. Bring to a boil and simmer for 2 minutes; remove from heat, cover, and let stand for 1 hour.
Add ham bone, diced ham, onion, salt, pepper, and bay leaf. Bring to a boil; reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer until beans are soft, about 1 hour and 15 minutes.
Add carrots and celery; cook until tender, about 10 to 15 minutes.
Remove ham bone from the pot and place on a cutting board until cool enough to handle. Remove any meat from the bones and cut into bite-sized pieces; stir into soup until warmed through.

review.reviewBody: Made it using ham steak (didn't have a bone), and canned beans (didn't have dried.) It was excellent!
Delicious, easy recipe that was satisfying on a chilly December night.

I used all Ingredients carrots onions celery and white soup beans of course I soaked over night and put in chicken broths to cook in I had a ham bone tossed that in cooked maybe 2 hours then after reading reviews I did end up adding a tbsp. of Worcestershire sauce and and 1/2 cup ketchup. wow it really brought the flavor out simmering right now will be making it with honey cornbread
Aromatic and full of flavor!
OH MY Goodness, Just like Grannie used to make. Awesome flavor, just add some corn bread with it and, you have quite a treat!!! Thanks so much.
It is easy and de-dog delicious!
Just like Grandma used to make! This is down- home comfort food. Grandma used the leftover ham bone from holiday dinners, or sometimes smoked pork hocks. Love it!
An old fashion recipe that is great today!

I just noticed that I printed this recipe in 2004 and I've been using it ever since. The only change I've made to is it doubling the amount of onions, carrots, and celery, and if I've got extra ham, I'll use that, too. It's definitely better the next day, but if I make it in the morning, it's almost got that leftover extra by suppertime! And, yes, I just noticed because it's for supper tonight!
Skip the added salt. Otherwise, excellent.

This was a fabulous recipe. I didn't have navy beans, so I used a variety pack of dried beans. (You know, the ones that have like 20 different types in them.) I found the soup very colorful with all the bean types.

Excellent basic navy bean soup recipe.
 I used chicken stock instead of water, and basically doubled the onion, celery and carrots, salt and pepper.
Excellent bean soup! I stick to the original recipe, I only double my veggies and add a little ketchup. I have been making this for years.

This is just how I remembered my Nannie making it. During Step 2 I also added 2 more cups of water and 2 chicken bouillon cubes. I then added the celery and carrots after 45 min to omit the 3rd step and let the soup cook for the remaining 30 minutes.
Very tasty. I added a bit of garlic salt.
Delicious without any salt added.

After the first boil and soak you should rinse the beans and then start over with fresh liquid, my preference is chicken stock and water, then add ham bone and bring back to a boil then I simmer for an hour and a half, then remove bone and bay leaf, then add prepared veggies and ham, simmer another hour. we like loaded so i add potatoes as well. i also mash a bit for thickening
It turned out great loved it very good

This was a bowl of bland. No depth of flavor. Toward the end I threw in some Liquid Smoke to try anything to gain some flavor, but it didn't help. We ate it, but it sure isn't anything like what mom or dad used to make. My cornbread was the only think that allowed me to eat this. Very sad as I was really looking forward to the flavors from when I was young. Won't make this again.
I added thyme

It turned out great! I used some suggestions for flavour and baking soda to help remove gas from the beans, also changed the water and used homemade vegetable bullion, minced an entire onion, added 2 garlic cloves.
Will make again
Made in crock pot for 6 hr. Turned out delicious! I just used ham from ham bone. Omitted the diced ham.
Best soup I've ever made.

Fantastic! I substituted Northern White beans because my store did not have navy. As others suggested, I used 4 C chicken broth with 3 C water, and I cooked in the slow cooker for 7 hours on low. Easy and delicious!
Standard traditional bean soup favorite!!
It was amazing! Like Campbell’s bean and bacon soup. I made it in the crockpot. It soaked all night and cooked all day on low. Salt to taste. Turned out great
Great for beginners! I made a lot of changes (adding Worcestershire and garlic) and it was awesome. Thank you. (Had a bunch of beans from the food bank but don't like beans lol)

I added 1/2 tsp cayenne pepper to give a
bit of zing.

Have this soup for years but I don't add carrots or celery as the grands don't like them. Never use broth or stock. Add lots of pepper and garlic of course some salt. Don't soak beans just start first thing on the morning and let it cook all day. Very good with corn bread!
One word... YUM!!! I followed the recipe except I had to had quite a bit more water as it got really thick. The end result was delicious! Thanks for sharing!
i cooked it for an hour then let it sit for an hour the beans were softer. Then cooked the rest as said,. tasted awesome,. Was so good hubby cooking it today,
I followed the recipe exactly and it was excellent. One note, I would prefer a little more carrots and celery. Just my personal preference.
With parsley too - yum
This is an excellent copy of my Grandmothers bean soup. Very simple and easy. You may have to adjust the amount of salt depending on the saltiness of the ham your using.

I made a few changes in this recipe.
First of all I used 4 large ham hocks that were smoked. I simmered the ham hocks in 8 cups water with two bay leaves for 3 hours. In another pot I boiled the beans two packages for 10 minutes and then repeated the process one more time , draining each time. After removing the ham from the ham hocks I also added more ham that I had in the freezer from a previous ham that I had cooked. Add your miraqua and the ham to the pot that you cook the ham hocks in then add chicken stock. You will find that there is more flavor in your broth and your bean soup will taste wonderful. Salt and pepper to taste.
I added extra celery, onion and I should have added more ham, I added 3 cups of water, glad I did because it would have been too thick.
Wonderful! Will make again!

I used pinto beans,"all I had"and a ham bone and drippings from when I heated the ham.Added about 3/4 lb. ham pieces 1 cup carrots,1 cup celery,1/2 onion. 2 bay leafs and 1 cup v8 was a little thin so mashed up a 1/3 cup of the beans. Season to taste. Will make it agin the same way. I do not soak my beans. I rinse them in cold water and then just simmer until tender that's when you add the v8. every thing else all goes in the pool right away.

I love this soup recipe! I mashed half the beans for texture, added a cup and a half of cubed potatoes and two tablespoons of hickory and brown sugar barbecue sauce. It tastes just like bean bean and bacon soup. My husband loved it!
I did no changes, never do the first time i make something new, this was good, ty
it was quite delicious. everyone in the house ate it. I threw it all in the Crock-Pot and let it cook all day.
I used hot itialian sausage, and added some spinach near the end. Topped off each bowl with some parmigiano cheese.

Excellent!! Only change I made was using stock instead of broth. I also thought it had too many beans for our liking, so I took out about a third of them, otherwise, made as written. Hubby even loved it and he's picky! Thank you for a great recipe for January!
Honestly the best bean soup soup ever had! The only things I did different was I left out the bay leaf and added potatoes.
The only change I made to this recipe was that I used 4 cups of low sodium chicken broth with 3 cups of water. Absolutely delicious!
Excellent, no changes.
My husband really like the clear broth on this bean soup. It still had great flavor.

I make this every year with leftover Easter ham. I leave out the ham bone. I don't like the gamey, marrowey flavor it imparts. I just add diced leftover ham which lends a ton of flavor. You don't need to add any extra spices, except for the bay leaf, salt and pepper in the recipe. The ham has all the seasoning you need. I use all of the leftover meat from the ham, I don't measure. Towards the end of the cooking time I take a stick blender or potato masher and mash up a good 10-20% of the beans to give the broth a rich hearty flavor and texture.

i used pinto beans 
put in pot cover with water soak overnight
add ingredients as posted but before adding carrots and celery drain soup and mash beans then add back to pot with ham cut off bone celery and carrot for about half hour delicious

Woo-Hoo I passed judgment 100000% I made it for my dear love. Okay so I have tried cooking many things for him that are just mom makes it better please ask her how to make it. WHAT oh well I came into this recipe and just knew this was it for the leftover Easter ham. I passed oh boy did I pass "this is as good as moms maybe a little better" Thank goodness Oh and I love it so good and so simple.
It was very great. I added extra ham and ended with a squirter of ketchup. Blended a bit of the soup for a creamer soup.

I read previous reviews andI boiled the beans for 10 minutes, took to the sink, added a handful of baking soda and stirred. I rinsed the beans thoroughly, added a quart of chicken broth, increased the vegetables to 1 cup and added a chopped clove of garlic. When done, I puréed 1 cup of the beans and added 1/4 cup of ketchup. Superb, especially served with a little cheddar jack on top!

I used Barb Maxwell's "Appalachian" advice with the baking soda... that was excellent. I used 3 small ham steaks from a butcher and just the bones from those steaks. I trimmed most of the fat but each steak had a rim of "rind" which i threw in while cooking. I used half water and half chicken stock. In the end I probably had more like 3+ cups of ham in it overall This is a very flexible recipe. The pot is still on the stove and I think it's excellent but will probably be even better tomorrow!

When I was making this recipe I was a little unsure if it would have enough flavour, boy was I wrong. The first night we made it we ended up not cooking it long enough. The next night we cooked it more until the meat fell off the bone. Sooo good.
it was very nice.
Awesome! The only thing different that I did was add a couple of chopped carrots. Even the grands loved it!
I added Pinto and Kidney beans. Also, some bacon and a little garlic. But over all it was pretty good and it freezes well.

This was a basic Bean Soup Recipe that we just loved. I used chicken broth instead of water. I put a little more ham it in than specified. I agree with others - it's even better the next day. When I make it again, I'll double the recipe and freeze what's left. I will make it again!
My husband said its the best ham and bean soup he's ever had! Can't wait to have leftovers tomorrow! (Used chicken broth instead of water)

Best Navy Bean Soup ever. My husband made this soup this AM after soaking the beans in water over night. He dumped that water out, then covered the beans with fresh water, boiled them and then rinsed them with cold water, doing this twice. This is to cut down on the gas that beans produces, especially at our Denver altitude of 5280 ft. He then made the recipe as stated but did use a ham bone and 4 cups chicken broth and 3 cups water. All was put in a crock pot on High for about 8 hours. Again that is because to cook dried beans here, they have to cook longer so adjust your time and temp. This is without a doubt the best recipe we have tried or eaten. Thanks so much for this great recipe.
Colorado Karen
This Ham and Bean soup recipe is wonderful! I made it as is and it was so good, I made it again a couple of days later!
Yummy!

I wish I had had the beans called for in the recipe because I know it would have been even better. It was really good, but I had to use black beans and pintos because that was what i had. Instead of water I used chicken stock. Otherwise I followed the recipe. I will make this again sometime after a trip to the grocery.
This should come with a warning"Highly addictive". I use a 16 bean mix, did the suggested boil twice and let sit for an hour and added chicken base to the water.

This soup was so good. I did what another person here stated, and i added about two tablespoons, or less, of flour and it thickened it up some. I should have mixed the flour with some water or something, because, at first, the flour created some lumps that i had to try to break them up. I added two ham hocks, and i usually make more than the recipe calls for. Very yummy! Thank you so much for this hearty, healthy recipe!! And thanks to all recipes dot com for teaching me how to cook. If it wasn't for all of the ratings and tips for each recipe, i would be lost.

Great recipe! The better one on here as far as 'soup beans' go. I did change the recipe a little. I tend to slow cook and the style of ham as well as the way it's made makes a difference. I used celery salt instead of celery and no carrots. I cooked over 4 pounds of beans so I used a whole yellow onion. I even diced pineapples from the ham and added them to the mix. Talk about feeding an Army. Love it! GREAT JOB!!

To the base recipe I substituted low-sodium chicken stock for half of the water, added one large clove of garlic, crushed and one 14.5 oz can of fire-roasted diced tomatoes. I also like a little vinegar in my bean soup as well as a little heat, so I added a bit of hot sauce. It turned out great and had several layers of flavor. Will definitely make again.

Great tasting soup, but I made a few modifications. First, I used canned Northern Beans, not dry, to save some time. I boiled and simmered the ham bone alone in the broth for 30 minutes. Then I added everything to it, all veggies at the same time, and added one clove of garlic. Boiled and simmered everything together for another 30 minutes. Comes out tasting great.
To those that say it was bland, a good quality ham makes a big difference. I smoked mine and my soup was outstanding. I also ignored the bay leaf and used more ham than it called for.
Was a basic bean soup. Try something different next time.
loved it!

I'm very happy with it. I pretty much just used this recipe as a guide. For the beans, I just used what I had, which was Pinto. Instead of using hamhocks in it, I just put some bouillon cubes (I put no meat in this soup). Since my boyfriend doesn't like celery, I substituted with some potatoes. I'll probably continue to use different things and adjust to my liking.

I think this is a great recipe, but it definitely needs seasoning. I added parsley, basil, oregano, thyme (1 tsp. each) and 1/2 tsp. Coleman's mustard and 1/4 tsp. nutmeg. I shredded the carrots and 2 potatoes as the potatoes thicken it up. When done, 30 minutes before serving, I added 2/3 cup sour cream. Yum! 

The other thing that I changed were the beans. I had several half-bags of different beans, (kidney, navy, pinto and another small bag of mixed, dry veggies/beans) and it was fabulous!

Oh yes, someone mentioned using soda, which works great, too, but my grandma used to put salt in her beans when she soaked them overnight. It was the easiest way to ALWAYS get the beans done properly, as sometimes the skin seemed tough. Amazing what 3 tsp. of salt added to the cold water did.

Nancy S
Very good soup! Followed recipe except drained water in beans following standing time and replaced with unsalted chicken stock and water 50/50 approximately 8 cups total.

Loved this soup! I used chicken broth, added a can of crushed tomatoes and garlic. I also fried bacon with the vegetables. Than made a roue(equal parts butter and flour) to thicken. It was incredible!

I didn't modify this other than using chicken broth instead of water (didn't add any extra salt then), and I used the fast boil/baking soda method to shorten the cook time. My 3-year-old had thirds! This is the one who doesn't even eat dinner usually! I thought it was super easy and tasty. Will be making again!
This is one of my favorite soup recipes! The only ingredient I modified is the salt. The ham and ham bone add enough saltiness for my taste.

We really loved this recipe. I fixed it as written except I used less beans and substituted half the water for chicken broth b/c I Did NOT use the bone. I cooked it in my new electric pressure cooker which i love. Just put it all in, program it, and it comes out perfect every time. Such an easy way to cook dried beans! Will be fixing again but will use the full bag of beans as written next time!

Minus 10 in Minnesota - thumbs down. This recipe - thumbs up! We followed the recipe as written with the exception of using a carton of chicken broth in place of 4 cups of water. Delicious - simple and elegant. Thank you Pat Keene.
This is an easy recipe and full of flavor!! I will NEVER use a different recipe. My whole family loved the soup. YUMMMM

Very simple with beautiful flavor. Like other reviewers, I used chicken broth and increased veggies from half to a full cup. I also used a total of 5 bay leaves, added thyme, and a pinch of savory. I did not have a ham bone, so I just threw in two strips of uncooked bacon for the flavor and fat. (I did use the diced ham.) I omitted the salt since it was in the broth. I threw everything in the pot brought it to a boil for 10 minutes and then low simmer for 1 hour with lid on. After, I took the lid off and let it cook down for added flavor for another 30 mins. Oh before I forget, I just soaked the beans overnight.

Ham and bean soup was something my mother always made when I was growing up. Since moving out, I've missed things like the smell of her cooking. But since we're so health conscious, and don't eat pork, I tried things a little different. Chicken thigh meat instead if ham, low sodium, and fresh bell peppers. Red pepper flakes are delicious too if you like it spicy!

This is great just the way it is written! My preference is a country or Smithfield ham bone/meat, but realize that they are not available everywhere. To put some of the ingredients that others suggest, ketchup, brown sugar, liquid smoke, etc., you must be kidding or from western PA like my husband who puts ketchup on everything. Please rate a recipe as written or post your own version as a separate recipe. Being a southern girl, this is the way to prepare navy bean soup!
I added chicken stock as some reviewers suggested, omitted the salt, and doubled the veggies. It turned out great!
After cooking the beans, added a few cups of chicken broth as there was not enough liquid. Adding pepper as I served it made it perfect! This is definitely a go to recipe!

This is a great recipe very similar to what my mom made while growing up. I would never use chicken stock or add tomatoes, however when eating a bowl add a teaspoon or two of malt vinegar, homemade garlic bread on the side makes a great meal.

The beans turned out wonderful. I followed the recipe for the most part but I made some modifications. I did 4 cups water and 4 cups chicken broth. I doubled the veggies...but I also added some additional seasoning (along with what was added already) to zest it up a little. I added 1 can of diced tomatoes (Italian style), 1/2 tsp paprika, 1/2 tsp cumin, 1/2 tsp garlic powder, 1/2 tsp garlic pepper and 1 tsp of Italian seasoning. It was delicious. All 4 of my kids loved it. Serve with warm corn bread!
So delicious!

This soup needs a ham base or chicken base for fuller flavor. Once added we liked this soup very much. I also have never soaked beans. I put everything in the pot to a boil then lower heat to simmer and cook for about 2 1/2 hours. Great on a cold winters day!
I used canned beans to cut the cooking time and smoked turkey wings to season the soup instead of ham since we dont eat pork. I also added ALOT more garlic! It was delicious
I let my beans soak overnight instead. And I add two ham hocks instead of one because that is the only way I can buy them around where I live and it turns out great each time.
Simple, easy and flavorful. I soaked my beans overnight. As long as I remember this step, I find it easier.

We always scoop out a cup of beans and mash them and then re-introduce to soup (well, hello there, beans), this extra thickening makes it uber-delicious. And if you grew up poor, like we did, you will put a big fat slice of bread in the bowl before you pour in the soup. None of us starved!

Very good! This was my first time using my leftover ham bone from Christmas dinner and soaking the dried beans as well. I used great northern beans and it turned out fabulously! I would not add any salt next time as it was plenty salty due to the ham. Also used some Swason's Flavor Booster and that probably increased the saltiness as well.
Delcious! Added beef broth instead of water. We loved it and will make it gain.
This soup is really good. I accidently left out the bay leaf and it was still good.

After years of searching for a great bean soup recipe, I've finally found it! The first time I made this, I used diced ham. It was good, but the second time I made it, I used 4 slices of bacon instead. That's the one I prefer. I put the bacon in raw and took out the large pieces when it was done cooking. I also added just a touch of brown sugar. I put everything in the crock pot on high (about 4 hours for navy beans and 5-6 hours for great northern beans), and didn't need to soak or precook the beans at all. If the beans start looking dry, just add a little more water and they'll be fine. Thank you so much for this recipe!

This was just like mom used to make. Well, with a few minor tweaks. I did drain and rinse the beans first.. I didn't need all that ham, just the ham off the bone. I added canned tomatoes that I had chopped finely WITH the juice. I also added one clove of garlic, and a lot more pepper, and just a touch of cayenne pepper, touch of ground cloves, and I used chicken broth I had left over for half the liquid. It's cooking now and I'm thinking about adding some thyme too!! Very good starter recipe to add your special touch to.

This is an excellent recipe - I added bits of bacon in addition to the ham (if it is handy). This is the first time I tried a recipe with veggies. Also and since my family likes the thicker soup I add the water, boil them down, add the water and boil them down the second time. A favorite at our house.
